awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  Corrosion Inhibition of Stainless Steel Alloys in High Temperature Chloride Salts for Concentrated Solar Power Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This STTR Phase II project will focus on the development of cost effective, high temperature molten salt heat transfer fluids for third generation concentrated solar power (CSP) plants with operating temperatures >700?C. In the Phase I of this research, an additive package was developed that formed an adherent ceramic oxide coating on 316/316L stainless steel at the temperatures >700?C when added to specific chloride salt blends and inhibit corrosion. The utilization of the inhibitor package strategy will enable the utilization of economical stainless-steel alloys in the CSP plants and would reduce the infra-structure cost. Such solutions will have a direct impact on the renewable energy market which would help to lower the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) for thermal solar from the current cost of 12?/kwh to the target 3?/kwh by 2030. The scientific and technological insight gained in this project could be beneficial to many other applications, such as molten carbonate fuel cells, thermal energy storage systems, nuclear molten fluoride/chloride reactors, and other high-temperature systems that are susceptible to aggressive corrosion. Incorporation of the inhibited molten chloride salt in the CSP plants will also provide sustainable green energy, reduce water usage, create more jobs and offer U.S. energy independence and security. On a societal level, impact will be achieved by the continued delivery and development of educational activities based on the research topics embodied by this work.


The core innovation in this proposed program is the development of a chemical mixture, an additive package that would minimize the corrosion of stainless steel induced by molten chloride salts at temperatures >700?C. The additive package reacts with the stainless steel and forms a corrosion inhibiting ceramic oxide coating in-situ when added to the molten chlorides at operating temperatures>700?C. The chloride salts are proposed to be the heat transfer fluids for third generation CSP plants. The feasibility of the inhibitor package strategy in a real world CSP plant will be critically assessed in this proposed research. A prototype bench scale molten test loop will be designed and built to mimic the flow conditions in a CSP plant. The effect of prolonged exposure to high temperature molten salts on the mechanical properties of the base metal under dynamic conditions will be studied with attention to the molten salt induced degradation of strength and toughness at elevated temperatures. The degradation behavior of the salt with the inhibitor package will be studied as well. Additional research will be performed to gain fundamental insight on the nucleation and growth of the ceramic oxide coating and its thermal and mechanical stability in dynamic flow conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Concentrating Solar Power (CSP) provides an efficient way of converting solar energy to electricity and heat. With the reduction in government subsidies, it is imperative to reduce the construction cost of CSP plants to make solar energy more cost-competitive and a more viable option. Higher efficiency along with the use of economical metal alloys for construction of the new CSP plants will help to cut down the installation and operating costs. This is feasible if the operating temperature of the power plants is >700°C. Molten chloride salts have been identified as a promising candidate for high-temperature heat transfer fluid for increased efficiency and excellent thermo-physical properties. However, there is no commercially viable solution available because of the extreme corrosivity of chloride salts towards the usual, cheaper ferrous alloys.

In this Phase II of the STTR project, the researchers developed a molten chloride salt blend which in presence of an additive package can form crystalline, protective layer on the economical stainless-steel alloys thereby preventing corrosion when these alloys are used at temperatures exceeding 700°C. The top protective layer forms within the first few hours of heat treatment at 750°C and the layer became more uniform on further heating. This top oxide arrested the growth of the underlying corrosion layer cutting down the corrosion thickness by more than 40%.  The stainless-steel coupons with the protective oxide coating were thermally cycled for up to 100 cycles to mimic the day and night hours in an actual steel plant. After the thermal cycling, the top layer remained adherent and provided corrosion protection.  Different post-corrosion cleaning methods were tested, and a hot water cleaning method was developed in this project. This method retained the protective oxide and removed the corrosion layers and worked quite well for corrosion rate measurements. The additive package reduced the corrosion rate of greater than 500 µm/year to weight gain due to the protective oxide on the stainless-steel alloys. A hot tank and loop were designed, capable of handling molten salt at temperatures > 800°C. The inhibited molten salt was circulated in this hot tank and loop set-up for several hundred hours using a high temperature stainless steel pump. The inhibitor layer protected the pump and the tank from failure. Presence of oxygen generally exacerbates the molten salt corrosion further and in an actual application, it is impossible design completely leak-proof system. One important finding was that the inhibitor package provided the stainless-steel alloys significant corrosion protection in oxygen containing atmosphere. Immersion corrosion testing, electrochemical testing and various high resolution analysis methods indicated the power of inhibitor, how it provided corrosion resistance to stainless steel under various conditions.

This grant project provided the graduate and undergraduate students valuable technical, hands-on skills as well as communication and team building abilities. All Dynalene personnel got training in safely handling high temperature furnace, equipment, and molten salt. Dynalene sales team is promoting the inhibited molten salt mixture through various avenues. Use of this product can help cut down the use of fossil fuels and promote renewable energy job opportunities.

 


Last Modified: 03/23/2022
Modified by: Sreya Dutta
